spanishExample: ¡Póngase esto, por favor!
englishTranslation: (formal) Put this on, please!
vocabIncluded: póngase: put on / become (Ponerse, formal imperative)

spanishExample: ¡Siquiera ponte aquí!
englishTranslation: At least get yourself here!

spanishExample: ¿Puedo ponerme esta ropa, siquiera para esta fiesta?
englishTranslation: Can I put on these clothes, at least for this party?

spanishExample: ¿Realmente tienes que poner eso ahí?
englishTranslation: Do you really have to put that there?
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Casi hice exactamente lo mismo.
englishTranslation: I almost did exactly the same thing.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"

spanishExample: Casi no *I ate* nada, ni siquiera *dessert.*
englishTranslation: I almost didn’t eat anything, not even dessert.

spanishExample: Igual, esto es demasiado grande para nuestra casa.
englishTranslation: Still, this is way too big for our house.

spanishExample: Las puso ahí, lo cual fue *a mistake.*
englishTranslation: He put them(f) there, which was a mistake.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things
lo cual: "which" without a specific noun (idiom)
puso: put, he/she/it put (Poner, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No quiere que la pongamos en *the trash,* ni siquiera si *it’s spoiled.*
englishTranslation: She doesn’t want us to put it(f) in the trash, not even if it’s spoiled.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pongamos: put, we put (Poner, subjunctive, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: No quiero que lo ponga ahí.
englishTranslation: I don't want him to put it there.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
ponga: put, he/she/it put (Poner, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No te pusiste triste tampoco.
englishTranslation: You didn’t get sad either.
vocabIncluded: ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"
pusiste: put, you put (Poner, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: No van a ponerse tristes, ni siquiera *at the end* de *the movie.*
englishTranslation: They aren’t going to get sad, not even at the end of the movie.
vocabIncluded: ponerse: any use of Poner with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to "become" or "put on"
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Quiero que ponga esto exactamente donde le digo.
englishTranslation: I want him to put this exactly where I tell him.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
ponga: put, he/she/it put (Poner, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Quiero que pongas las cosas en su lugar.
englishTranslation: I want you to put the things in their place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
pongas: put, you put(Poner, subjunctive, 2nd person plural)

spanishExample: Quizá no *she likes* tanto esa ropa.
englishTranslation: Maybe she doesn’t like those clothes so much.

spanishExample: Quizás ellas tampoco la quieran tanto.
englishTranslation: Maybe they(f) don’t love her so much either.

spanishExample: Quizás sea demasiado *expensive* para ellos.
englishTranslation: Maybe it would be way too expensive for them.

spanishExample: Realmente no puse las cosas donde las tenía que poner.
englishTranslation: I really didn’t put the things where I had to put them.
vocabIncluded: las: "them" as a direct object for feminine people/things
puse: put, I put (Poner, preterite, 1st person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Sé que no es tu *style;* igual te lo tienes que poner.
englishTranslation: I know it’s not your style; still, you have to put it on.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Si ponen esto aquí, quizá él no *would complain* tanto.
englishTranslation: If they put this here, maybe he wouldn't complain so much.
vocabIncluded: ponen:put, they put (Poner, present, 3rd person plural)
